title: What technological advance do you fear most in the next ten years? - Quora

response.answer_text: I do not fear any particular technology, but I do fear a particular sociological development driven by technology. I fear the snowflaking of the big social and ecommerce by the left. These systems are firmly in the grip of the country’s left wing, and are deploying their power to attack and damage conservatives and libertarians. The demonetization of conservative videos, the clearly biased “fact checking” systems which never seem to call out left wing sites and pundits for their mistakes and dishonesty, the vicious treatment handed out to Jame Damore and his colleague at Google, the list goes on and on and on. There are more subtle things taking place. For instance, Amazon censoring independent book author’s covers if they have have a picture of a hot chick holding a gun. That’s OK for James Bond novels, but you, uh, no. Everyone knows that pictures of hot chicks holding guns leads to guys who can’t get dates shooting up schools. We need David Hogg, gun control’s own mini me version of Elmer Gantry, to get cracking on the entire issue. Amazon has entirely too much power in the book industry. If movie studios were told by the government they couldn’t own theaters, then Amazon, which has achieved a monopsony in ebook distribution, should be told to get out of the ebook publishing business. The Zon has rigged the pricing market for indie authors, controls the most prominent review site (Goodreads), controls the industry standard format for publishing ebooks, sends out creepy bots to censor reviews if god forbid you and another person happen to be in the same online meetup group, etc., etc., etc. That’s way too much literary and publishing power concentrated in the hands of an organization with a clear left wing bias. I will be writing in greater detail about these issues in the third edition of “In Search of Stupidity: Over 20 (now 30) Years of High-Tech Marketing Disasters.” (If you’ve read this and are interested in receiving an advanced review copy, my contact info is up on the Softletter website. I’m starting to put the list together now.) Rick Chapman Managing Editor and Publisher, Softletter Author: Selling Steve Jobs’ Liver. A Story of Startups, Innovation, and Connectivity in the Clouds” “In Search of Stupidity: Over 20 Years of High-Tech Marketing Disasters” “SaaS Entrepreneur: The Definitive Guide to Succeeding in Your Cloud Application Business”

I fear Artificial Intelligence (AI) the most. Ten years? Forget about ten years! AI will start to take over thousands of jobs in the next ten months. I closely follow exponential technologies. The advances in this new industry are starting to get scary. Here’s one example just reported by Mr. Gates: 
 If that’s not enough, take a look at this quick video:  AI will replace millions of customer service jobs sooner than we could even imagine. Call centers will soon be something of the past. If you have access to Netflix, don’t miss this fantastic documentary:  Also a Google technology: AlphaGo | Netflix Be informed and anticipate changes. Reacting is not enough anymore.

Personally, I fear AI the most, but in the next 10 years, I fear people’s reaction to AI more than the AI itself. AI will certainly allow fewer people to do certain jobs than have been needed in the past. Joblessness and underemployment will lead to societal problems but it may not be easy for society to diagnose and solve those problems within the next 10 years. The result will be an increase in crime and more anti-elitism and populism. In a similar vein, manufacturing is poised to be revolutionized. There are certain manufacturing jobs that are still labor intensive and require humans. These are the jobs that are often done in developing countries because labor tends to be cheaper there. As it happens, robotics advances will be coming online in the next decade that will likely render many of those jobs unnecessary. You won’t be able to point to any specific technological advance that did it because it will actually be a series of small, seemingly innocuous advances. Unfortunately, this is all happening at a time when technological advances are driving significant medical advances. That means the need for people to work is going to go up. Together, these have the potential to upend our world trade and social system and it is coming (or even causing) a shift in how we relate to each other. I think we are unlikely to have the optimal reaction to these changes within the next decade, though I remain hopeful about the next century.

Hi, there! It’s a rather interesting question. Every now and then I ask myself about it, but the matter of fact is that I don’t fear any technological advances. Moreover, I am sure that technologies are designed to make life easier for people. So if you don’t mind, I will focus on the most promising trends of the next decade including: Mobile commerce. Time is money and mobile payments are intended to save this time for life. This technology is also very useful for retailers as merchants could be in instant contact with customers. No random movements, no needs to go shopping in the mall - everything is on your phone, just click and pay. Card-to-cloud transition. Contactless cards are already the common part of the daily life. As recent surveys show, UK in-store contactless payments overtake PIN and chip: June analysis has 51% of such transactions being contactless, July has 52%. But it’s still not enough for today’s customers. People spent almost half of the day glued to the screens of gadgets, so merchants try to meet consumer’s needs. As a result, card-to-cloud transition may happen in the nearest future. There are other fintech technologies that will definitely have an impact on our lives and lives of the next generation. You can read here more about these trends. Summing up my answer: I am not afraid of any technological advances and I am still sure that they will make our life easier. Thank for the question, Rick Wilz ;)

The problem is that any technology which could be a danger is also a technology which could be a benefit. AI is the obvious big bogey-man, but AI also has the potential to free humanity from drudgery, and if fusion power is achieved so we have plentiful energy, AI can free us from poverty as well. Even low-level AI is making a difference. One example is court issues: I had a problem a while back with an officer who was trying to find any way at all to get me into jail (to the extent of issuing a citation for “misappropriation of state resources” — for building a dam in a creek on the beach!), but no way could I afford a lawyer. But I found a place that uses AI to find past related cases, and using it I got a list of precedents, several dozen of them including some from an angle I wouldn’t have thought of. Using those, I put together my case and pretty much wiped the floor with the officer — who was warned by the judge against harassing and persecuting! Even good sides of AI have a down side: automated calls from doctors and others make sure we’re reminded of appointments, but they also mean employees aren’t needed any longer to make reminder calls; automated calls about products save us from having to try to figure out what the call is even about because of thick foreign accents, but they also mean that the employees who used to do that are now out of jobs. Hector Quintanilla illustrates this with the video about Google assistant: thousands of people now employed at call centers will be losing their jobs, and probably within the year, not ten. So the technology we can most welcome is also the technology we can most fear.

I also fear AI for the lose of jobs it will produce and the vast amount of people it will displace from work . One of the big worries is where will it receive all its information from ? If you look at the first few pages on the internet on any given subject up will come the answers governments and other interesting parties will want you to see/hear. Will this be how it will build up its dater base? So two things I looked up recently. When did slavery in Africa start? first answer up 15th century by the Portuguse. No for ever, its always been there the 1st major slave revolt was in 840 in the present day Iraq. How do women get cervical cancer? no mention of the face that women who sleep with many partners are more likely to get it than those who don’t. So what information will AI produce only that which they want us to know very dangerous!

I know nothing about AI and I don’t follow any news regarding it. Call it fate, but I was just thinking about writing something related to this and viola, an answer by Hector Quintanilla lands me on this question. I guesstimate that the situation may lead to various scenarios - AI will develop at a steady pace and displace a lot of jobs (incl white collared ones). This may result in unrest at best and complete Armageddon at worst without careful planning. There would be a war of sorts between those who don’t want AI in their lives v/s those who want to implement it. This will be a messy affair and a victory of any side would not be beneficial to humanity in the long run. If the Pro-AI party wins, they would lose sense of their humanity as they would have massacred a lot of their fellow humans for a selfish goal. If the against group wins, well, they would have stopped technological evolution, but not for long, as people of the next generation will get curious and carry out the remaining works, which would make the war meaningless. This is the negative scenario.On a positive scenario, people may be open to AI displacing their jobs and making their lives more efficient. But, as one answer on Quora said (unable to recall), it is the distribution of existing resources which will be the major problem. There is enough for everyone’s need, but not enough for one’s greed. (MK Gandhi). Humans are greedy and selfish, wanting more and more. That is the reason development has taken place till now. That will have to change. The concept of Global Basic Income will become the talk of the century. For that, people have to discuss and work in a sensible and pragmatic way, which, based on the present human generation’s, behaviour, wouldn’t be feasible. If the distribution stage is planned perfectly, we are in for the best lives the world could offer.People can truly not worry about survival anymore. Even today, we are still on survival mode, with money being the major driving factor. That wouldn’t be the factor anymore and we would be free to follow our wishes.Sports, Arts and other related activities would be our priorities. There will still be some issues caused by human behaviour i.e jealousy, but that would be tackled by placing some agreed upon global guidelinesFarming/ Horticulture and similar relaxing activities would also be popular. Food scarcity would not be an issue too.Those who are naturally and truly interested in furthering AI development would live in a center researching on AI development and maintenance.Those who want to focus on space exploration will be free to do and also be aided very much by robots that could offer more efficient help than most humans could ever offer.All in all, people will be able to truly ‘follow their passion’ and not bother about money/survival etc.Or, you know, Robots turn sentient, an Matrix/iRobot/ Terminator scenario where Robots are in control of humans and whatever happens in the movies might happen for real.I have fun thinking various scenarios based on what I know. This one was on my mind last night and thankfully, I got it out on writing very soon. Personally, scenario 1 is more realistic right now than 2. I truly want this aspect to to become more relevant soon, preferably within my lifetime.

Directed energy weapons going mainstream. There has been a lot of testing of microwave cannons and other types of secret squirrel things for decades, and thus far the data has not been shared or stolen. But that will change I am sure. If a roque group with money is able to point one with any accuracy at satellites and starts shutting them down it could begin a chain of wrecks out there which will effectively shut down manned space exploration for decades.  Same problems with nut jobs pointing their emitters at airliners. I doubt the FCC has many detector/tracker gizmos out there that can react fast enough to catch a mobile “ray gun".  Now let's hear all the real scientist rebuttals.

Robocalls are easy to eliminate problems with - require SIP trunks to use the number assigned to the trunk, by the company, as its callerID. At least the country and area codes. When you see a call coming from country code 63, you can block all calls coming from country code 63, unless you know someone in the Philippines. My only fear with technology is that when the time comes, they won’t have the technology to save my life. (I’m 77, so I think of things like that.) I’m not a technophobe. I still can’t wait for the JWT to start giving us some results. I just genned a new computer (from components I chose). I maintain my own websites (and write code for them). So I don’t fear technology - as technology. We’re not going to be “taken over” by AI, but we might get something that doesn’t throw a page of Google hits at you as the “answer” to a question. But as far as what the future holds … maybe a way of predicting the future. We can’t do that yet.

1. Asteroid Mining  Asteroid mining is a modern day gold rush that will open a trillion-dollar industry and provide a near infinite supply of metals and water to support our growth both on this planet and off. More asteroids are discovered near earth everyday, which are easier to reach than moon and there are thousands of candidates. In the future they will be the source of near infinite supply of precious resources. 2. Recording and Replaying Dreams  Scientis in Japan have been working on a machine that would allow this. While researchers have so far only created technology that can reproduce simple images from the brain, the discovery paves the way for the ability to unlock people’s dreams and other brain processes. 3. Cloud Cities  Floating cities in some form on Venus is actually not the dumbest thing. It’s more appealing than Mars in some ways. While it may not be happening in our lifetime, it may well be a more serious plan in the future.

I don’t fear technological advances. I fear abuses of technology by people with malicious intentions, and I fear fragility caused by highly interdependent networks. There used to be a rumor that the Internet was designed in such a way that it could resist a nuclear strike, because it’s decentralized. That was never quite true. The domain name servers are decentralized, and that’s good, but there are enough bottlenecks in the cabling that one idiot with a backhoe can accidentally cut off Internet service to millions of people. As emergency services become ever more dependent on the Internet, this puts lives at risk. I’d like to see more redundancy built into the system to reduce its fragility.

We wouldn’t mind if, as predicted imminently by great panels of US experts, even no: jobs, banks, markets, utilities, car, fuel, energy (California is reportedly verging thus + massive bush fires), water, partner, security or happiness...? That is what I set out to prove. Our home is claimed to be about the most Self-Sufficient in Australia (original $10,500 cost) where weapons luckily are forbidden. Best to live near the sea breezes & not down-wind from factories, mines, nor near potential nuclear targets etc. House is high-set with garage & workshop under to save garden space & enable flood-fire-proof, also more insect-proof + better view + stronger breezes. Our huge west windows for noon till sunset winter house-heating. Wonderful wide veranda for morning warming at winter breakfasts. No Worries!!

IoT. as an advancement in the use of the internet it seems harmless enough but my concerns lie in the fact that it touches everything, and is likely to be deployed with a minimum of security, certainly if cost is a driving factor it will suffer shortfalls as with many other technologies that seem to be deployed in their millions and then after the event recognised as vulnerable. Until we have a standard for capability and security with no deployment of services until passed testing, there is little hope of holding down a set of rules. So until then everything is potentially vulnerable and the higher the number of devices the more potential they store.

IoT’s are electronic hardware software gadgets that are present inside or in the vicinity of other gadgets ( E.g Fridge, Cooking Range, Industry Plants ) that control function and operations and can be interacted over internet by humans or non-humans AI ( Artificial Intelligence ) robots. IoT’s will be pretty popular and will be present in every Commercial industry, Govt Buildings, Military installations and average home too. Abuse of IoT ( Internet Of Things ) by Hackers then will be the most fear in next ten years. If somebody has studied Computer Engineering / Information technology - They should do specialization in the field of Ethical Hacking and be Internet security specialist. There will be a great demand of people specialized in this field.

Well, I believe that there are numerous technological advances that would be dangerous to all human beings. But there are advances that will improve our lives and advance our society. I fear hoverboards because if there flying they could hit us by accident. Also, there will be microchips that will be like our brains which I do fear, because it’s dangerous to mimic the brain or try to implant this chips in our brains. Our brains are the most complicated , complex organs that scientist still don’t understand fully all the functions of the brains. I also fear drones because if anyone can buy one, they could invade our privacy by flying over our homes. They are also dangerous because many countries use drones as weapons to kill people.

In the next 10 years, AI/ML will demonstrate the lie that increased technology adds more jobs than it replaces— this was never true (at least since the introduction of the assembly lines in the ‘20s), but world history including the devastation of WWII, the re-industrialization of most of Western Europe, and the industrialization of most of the rest of the world (especially the far east) temporarily covered this up. We either come up with a way to distribute the world’s resource more equitably, or wind up with a world of “haves” and “have nots,” and more or less constant civil war as each set of “haves” is replaced by a new set.

Most thinkers are rightly afraid that the Artificial Intelligence technology is likely to jeopardize jobs for most people. Another significant worrisome effect of forthcoming technological advances is a scathing attack on the privacy of people. With Google maps, one can now see what is lying in one’s courtyard. With a rise in the population of drones, one can now see how some people are passing their lonely moments. With the forthcoming technology of self driven cars, it might become possible to “cut and paste” people. With improvements in the object detection technology, it will now be possible to detect people wearing precious jewelry. The Internet is then likely to widen the gap between rich and poor.

I’m not a conspiracy theorist but there’s no way in hell I’d get a chip with my personal and financial information put into a chip and onto my I.D. or in my body to make life ‘safer and easier’. Computers are still unreliable, fallible, hackable, and full of viruses, bugs, flaws, and commercial advertising. We’ve already given up so much freedom for security and convenience. I don’t want to walk into into a supermarket and have a computer say, “Welcome back, here to buy more toilet paper?” Count me out.

If robots aren’t owned by NASA, or another public agency, then they will bring about mass unemployment. People will riot when they show up for work and a semi-trailer of robots is off-loading behind the locked fence and the robots all turn and look them in the eye and say, “Why are you here? Didn’t anybody tell you that you were fired?” This is it must be outlawed, right now, for private concerns to have security robots armed with guns. Or your boss will have his business protected by a robot with a gatling gun for each arm — just like the ED 209 in the movie, Robocop.

Geneticide Gene targeted viruses. A virus could be tailored to attack only cells with a particular gene or set of genes. Target anyone from an individual to any size genetically linked group…from one to everyone. Or say, to target that rare species which is preventing exploitation of nature Why this? Genetic engineering doesn’t require hugely expensive equipment nor a huge amount of education—and it is getting easier daily. Like many projects most parts can even be contracted out or purchased off the shelf. The combined potential risk, low entry cost and relative simplicity make it an “everyman’s planet buster.”

Fear of the future? Lots, but not about technology. Do you know 5hat lots of people lost work when the wheel was invented? All those people used to be gainfully employed carrying stuff in their backs. The chariot was even worse. Not to mention all the arrowhead makers going out of business when bronze spears could be made! Not to mention having horses being used! Stopping innovation is Luddism. What we have seen is that stopping advances is really a bad idea. We do not lead the lives of our ancestors, and “pastoralism” is a myth. My dad was involved in the making of the first numerical controlled lathe, and a friend of Norbert Weiner. AI was predicted back in those days, and “fear of the future” has been along for a great many years. But it is an irrational fear. Chronophobia is bad enough, Technophobia makes no sense. Unless we uninvent the wheel.

Green energy systems. They do a lot of damage to the environment, and impact our ability to suply power. generally new cutting edge tech isn't a threat, just disruptive. But normally very beneficial to more then the few it hurts, the the few howl louder. ;) some things ( like a concept for fusion warheads ignighted from chemical explosives, rather then nuclear bombs ) could cause a lot of damage by extreamists and force us to deal with them as a issue, rather then shrugging them off.

I mostly don’t fear technological advance, but I suppose there are a few unsettling possibilities, including More and more invasive tech and the general disappearance of privacy Horrific weapons developments Advanced malware that can blow up your system and is hard to even detect much less combat Ads becoming incredibly aggressive and omnipresent Jerks reacting against environmental measures and making their vehicles extra polluting and so on (already happening)

Technology is just a collection of tools. Tools are neutral. It is the intention of the people using the tools that can be a problem for the greater good of everybody. If a lot of people continue to emphasize chakra 1,2 and 3 in their thinking , the new devices will be used for the domination of others. The real key is for people to do the inner work to move into chakra 6,7 and 8 thinking. Then the tools will be used to increase the well beingof everybody.

The Storing of human consciousness in digital format. I know that this technology may be a long way off but it concerns me the most. I think there is more to the human existance than our electrical impulses. Storing of our consciousness in a digital medium (like the TV show Altered Carbon) will cheapen the human existance and give people a false sense of immortality.

0:00-0:30 This is a video of a vlogger buying drinks just with a scan of his face in Shanghai. It is what I envisioned for the future, personally for me, I embrace technological advances as they're vital and inevitable. However, one issue I do take note is the health aspect. For example, with the prevalence of smart phones, those of the younger generations are more addicted than ever.

SUper artificial intelligence - the world is not nearly ready for fhis but there are so many players pushing for it. With quantum processors starting to come online I think it is only a matter of time. Elon musk even predicred the first country to get atrue super AI would probably start world war 3.
Lethal autonomous weapon - Wikipedia Ban on killer robots urgently needed, say scientists

Artificial Intelligence. It's pretty much replacing most jobs with automation and developing at a really fast pace. With the dawn of quantum computing, this will only progress faster and pretty much take more jobs from people. So yes this is what I fear the most about technology.

All efforts to curb robocalls fails. Like a bacteria that just mutates into a drug-resistant form… the robocall systems evolve, adapt, improvise… overcome. By 2030, 99.9 % of all network traffic is spam.

Well, every form of tech is helpful as well as threatening. I think it would be: AI (Artificial Intelligence).  Yeah, many people predict that if AI comes, of course, it would make the lives of people more easy, but would take away people’s jobs also. So, not sure exactly in the next 10 years. But, it could happen. Humans, we, have to know how to control and manage the situation.
I don’t fear the technology of the self-driving vehicle and drone delivery, but the jobcopolypse they’ll bring will force some unpleasant realities to be recognized.

Automated genetic modification systems. They already exist, but will continue to get more effective and less expensive. This is a greater risk than any other area of technology as far as difficult to control misuse or intentional abuse.
The same technology that has been feared for decades: Nuclear Weapons. The fact that they exist speaks volumes about humanity's priorities.

This continuous collection of personal data for advertising dollars. People are going to have to develop strategies to deflect manipulation on the part of advertisers to spend money the way they want you too.

My father always maintained that work could solve all of our problems. I think he would have advised that we help the migrants build their own habitats, grow their own food, care for their own sick, and educate their own children, etc. when feasible, wherever we could afford to do so.
I am in fear that I maybe will be not successful in helping humanity reach superintelligence and general AI. I have invented a whole new type of science.
The rollout of some of the extremely destructive high-tech military hardware that is being developed. The sophisticated rollout of dirty bombs. Stuff like that.
Reading the other answers, from people of good will who can at least follow the technicalities I can't follow, I don't worry any more.
Artificial intelligence, robotics and brain computer interfaces both fascinate me and scare me. They could give a lot to humanity or also cause a dystopian future.
Not fear but hope that energy will be produced out of nothing .
I don't "fear" any technological advance. The only people who fear technology are those who aren't intelligent enough to understand it.
Autonomous, Nano-sized Drones and Robots and Human Brain clones
Weaponized consumer drones
A.I mixed with robotics,Hehe! What if we create something that becomes uncontrollable
Why don’t you ask people who aren’t afraid?
